description: Uncertain. Perhaps from Scots brash, brasch (“a violent onset; an attack or assault”). Perhaps also related to Dutch bars (“stern; strict”), German barsch (“harsh; unfriendly”), Danish barsk (“harsh; rough; tough”), Swedish barsk (“harsh; impetuous”).

adjectives.description: brash (comparative brasher or more brash, superlative brashest or most brash)

entries.meaning: (of people or behaviour) Overly bold or self-assertive to the point of being insensitive, tactless or impudent; shameless.
examples: Synonyms: audacious, brassy, brazen, cocky, undiplomatic
a brash young businessman; a brash tabloid; a brash sense of humour

entries.meaning: (of actions) Overly bold, impetuous or rash.
(of things) Bold, bright or showy, often in a tasteless way.
examples: Synonyms: flashy, garish, loud, splashy; see also Thesaurus:gaudy

entries.meaning: A rash or eruption; a sudden or transient fit of sickness.

verbs.description: brash (third-person singular simple present brashes, present participle brashing, simple past and past participle brashed)

description: Compare American English bresk, brusk (“fragile, brittle”).

adjectives.description: brash (comparative brasher or more brash, superlative brashest or most brash)

entries.meaning: (US, colloquial, dated) Brittle (said e.g. of wood or vegetables).
Leaf litter of small leaves and little twigs as found under a hedge.
(geology) Broken and angular rock fragments underlying alluvial deposits.
examples: Alluvium differs from the rubble or brash , just described , as being composed of sand and gravel , more or less rolled
The sea dashed in an angry surf over its inclined sides, rattling the icy fragments or “brash” against its irregular surface
